de.susebox.jtopas
Class PluginTokenizer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer
        |
        +--de.susebox.jtopas.PluginTokenizer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Tokenizer
Deprecated. replaced by the implementations of Tokenizer and TokenizerProperties

public class PluginTokenizer
extends AbstractTokenizer

This class is an extension to AbstractTokenizer. It can be used instead of (InputStreamTokenizer when that class is not approbriate for the situation of the user (for instance, if its performance is to low).

There is another aspect to the PluginTokenizer: While the basic interface Tokenizer requires to add special sequences, comments etc. prior to the tokenizing process, the PluginTokenizer allows a more lazy approach. It is possible to start tokenizing without such properties and leave the decision completely to the pluggins that can be associated with an instance of this class. Only the enumeration methods like Tokenizer.getSpecialSequences() won't generally return anything.

Using this class is deprecated in favour of the new Tokenizer and TokenizerProperties interfaces and their implementations.

Author:
Heiko Blau
See Also:
Tokenizer, AbstractTokenizer

read

protected int read(char[] cbuf,
                   int offset,
                   int maxChars)
            throws java.lang.Exception
Deprecated. 
Implements the abstract method AbstractTokenizer.read(char[], int, int) by wrapping the InputStreamReader.read() call of the JDK standard class InputStreamReader.

Specified by:
read in class AbstractTokenizer
Parameters:
cbuf - buffer to receive data
offset - position from where the data should be inserted in cbuf
maxChars - maximum number of characters to be read into cbuf
Returns:
actually read characters or -1 on an end-of-file condition
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - anything that could happen during read, most likely IOException

setSource

public void setSource(TokenizerSource dataSource)
Deprecated. 
Setting the source for the tokenizer. Note that any data read from a previous source are lost. Position, line and column counting will start from 0. With this method it is possible to use one tokenizer on more than one source. A common example is a list of files that are to be processed.

Parameters:
dataSource - the new source for the AbstractTokenizer.read(char[], int, int) method

getSource

public TokenizerSource getSource()
Deprecated. 
Retrieving the current source. Note that the Tokenizer probably read ahead a huge part or even all data from this source.

Returns:
the current source of the tokenizer

setKeywordHandler

public void setKeywordHandler(KeywordHandler handler)
Deprecated. 
Setting a new KeywordHandler or removing any previously installed one. If null is passed (installed handler removed), the tokenizer will fall back to the base implementation.

Parameters:
handler - the (new) KeywordHandler to use or null to remove it

getKeywordHandler

public KeywordHandler getKeywordHandler()
Deprecated. 
Retrieving the current KeywordHandler. The method may return null if there isn't any handler installed. That does not mean, that keywords are not dealt with. Keyword detection is done by the base method of AbstractTokenizer in that case.

Returns:
the currently active whitespace keyword or null, if the base implementation is working

isKeyword

protected TokenizerProperty isKeyword(int startingAtPos,
                                      int length)
Deprecated. 
This method checks if the character sequence starting at a given position with a given lenght is a keyword. If so, it returns the keyword description as TokenizerProperty object. If the method needs to build a string from the character sequence it may use AbstractTokenizer.getText(int, int) or AbstractTokenizer.getTextUnchecked(int, int) to retrieve it.

Overrides:
isKeyword in class AbstractTokenizer
Parameters:
startingAtPos - check at this position
length - the candidate has this number of characters
Returns:
TokenizerProperty describing the keyword or null

This method checks if the character is a whitespace. It will use an installed WhitespaceHandler or switch back to the base implementation.

Overrides:
isWhitespace in class AbstractTokenizer

Returns:

readWhitespaces

protected int readWhitespaces(int startingAtPos,
                              int maxChars)
                       throws TokenizerException
Deprecated. 
This method detects the number of whitespace characters starting at the given position. It should use Tokenizer.getChar(int) to retrieve a character to check.
The method should return the number of characters identified as whitespaces starting from and including the given start position.
Do not attempt to actually read more data or do anything that leads to the change of the data source or to tokenizer switching. This is done by the tokenizer framework.

Overrides:
readWhitespaces in class AbstractTokenizer
Parameters:
startingAtPos - start checking for whitespace from this position
maxChars - if there is no non-whitespace character, read up to this number of characters
Returns:
number of whitespace characters starting from the given offset
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

isSeparator

protected boolean isSeparator(char testChar)
Deprecated. 
This method checks the given character if it is a separator. Implement Your own code for situations where this default implementation is not fast enough or otherwise not really good.

Overrides:
isSeparator in class AbstractTokenizer
Parameters:
testChar - check this character
Returns:
true if the given character is a separator, false otherwise

isSequenceCommentOrString

protected TokenizerProperty isSequenceCommentOrString(int startingAtPos)
                                               throws TokenizerException
Deprecated. 
This method checks at the given position if it contains a a special sequence. If a SequenceHandler is installed then it will be used to identify the starting sequences of comments, strings or single special sequences. The SequenceHandler informs the Tokenizer about the maximum possible length of any of these sequences (see SequenceHandler.getSequenceMaxLength()).
That way the tokenizer is able to provide a sufficient amount of data to the SequenceHandler. If there are less characters than the maximum length provided, the Tokenizer is near EOF.
The

Overrides:
isSequenceCommentOrString in class AbstractTokenizer
Parameters:
startingAtPos - start checking for sequences from this position
Returns:
a TokenizerProperty if a special sequence was found at the given position or null otherwise
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream
